item.description:
Welcome 👋

Linux Distributions: An Overview

Linux distributions, often referred to as “distros,” are various versions of the Linux operating system that package the Linux kernel, software, and libraries to provide a complete operating system for users. Each distribution caters to different needs, ranging from general-purpose desktop environments to specialized systems suited for servers or scientific computing.

What is a Linux Distribution?

A Linux distribution is a collection of software that includes:

  • The Linux kernel: Essential for interacting with your hardware.
  • System libraries and utilities: These are tools that allow the user to manage and interact with the system.
  • Package management system: Tools to install, update, and manage installed software applications.
Common Features of Linux Distributions
  • Open Source: Most distributions are free to use, modify, and distribute.
  • Community Support: Active communities provide forums, documentation, and support for users.

Popular Linux Distributions

Distribution Target Audience Features
Ubuntu General users User-friendly, large community, motivational documentation.
Fedora Developers and tech enthusiasts Cutting-edge features, focuses on free software.
CentOS Server environments Stability and long-term support; great for enterprise deployment.
Debian Advanced users and servers Known for its stability, extensive package repositories.
Arch Linux Advanced users Rolling release model emphasizes user control and customization.

Unique Characteristics of Popular Distros

  1. Ubuntu: Known for its ease of use; ideal for newcomers to Linux.
  2. Fedora: It offers the latest features and software with a focus on free and open-source software.
  3. CentOS: Derivative of Red Hat Enterprise Linux, it’s favored for server deployments due to its rock-solid stability.
  4. Debian: It is known for its rigorous testing and focus on stability.
  5. Arch Linux: A minimalistic approach allows users to create a custom Linux environment tailored to their needs.

![Linux Distribution Usage Graph]((https://kodprog.ru/img/articles-images/39.jpg)
Figure 1: Linux Distribution Usage by Percentage

Choosing the Right Distribution

Choosing the right Linux distribution largely depends on your needs:

  • For beginners, Ubuntu or Linux Mint are highly recommended due to their user-friendly interfaces and community support.
  • For users looking for a specific application or environment—like scientific computing—Debian or Fedora may be better suited.
  • CentOS and Red Hat are preferred for enterprise environments due to their stability and long-term support.

Docker and Linux Distros

Another aspect of Linux distributions is their compatibility with container technologies like Docker. This is crucial for developers and system administrators as it allows them to deploy applications in a lightweight and isolated environment.

![Docker on Linux]((https://kodprog.ru/img/articles-images/39.jpg)
Figure 2: Docker Architecture on Linux Distributions

Conclusion

Linux distributions offer a plethora of options tailored to various users’ needs, whether for desktop use, server management, or specialized applications. With their open-source nature, users can select and customize distros that best fit their requirements, ensuring extensive flexibility and resources within their operating systems. The Linux community’s supportive nature makes transitioning to or experimenting with these distributions accessible for everyone.

Further Reading

To dive deeper into any specific Linux distribution, consider exploring official documentation or community forums. Resources like LinuxQuestions or DistroWatch are also excellent starting points.

item.title: 👩🏼‍🏫 Scientific programming languages
item.description:
Python, C++, HTML, C, C#

These programming and markup languages ​​have different purposes and areas of application. Let’s take a closer look at each of them.

1. Python

  • Description: Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its simplicity and readability. It supports many programming paradigms, including object-oriented, imperative, and functional.
  • Application areas:
  • Scientific computing and data analysis (with libraries such as NumPy and Pandas).
  • Web development (used by frameworks such as Django and Flask).
  • Artificial intelligence and machine learning (with libraries such as TensorFlow and scikit-learn). 🐍

2. C++

  • Description: C++ is an extension of the C language that adds support for object-oriented programming. C++ gives developers more control over memory management and is effective for systems programming.
  • Application areas:
  • Developing operating systems and system software (e.g. Microsoft Windows).
  • Creating games and graphical applications (using Unreal Engine).
  • Embedded systems and high-load applications.💻

3. HTML

  • Description: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is a standard markup language for creating web pages. It is used to structure content on the Internet.
  • Application areas:
  • Creating the structure of web pages (e.g. headings, paragraphs, lists, and links).
  • Combination with CSS and JavaScript to develop modern web applications. 🌐
  • Image:

4. C

  • Description: C is a procedural programming language known for its performance and efficiency. It is considered a “low-level language” compared to modern languages ​​because it provides lower-level memory capabilities.
  • Application areas:
  • Systems programming (operating systems, compilers).
  • Embedded systems and device drivers.
  • Scientific applications that require high performance. ⚙️

5. C#

  • Description: C# is a modern, object-oriented programming language developed by Microsoft as part of the .NET platform. C# has a syntax similar to C++ and Java, and provides many built-in features.
  • Application areas:
  • Developing Windows and web applications (using ASP.NET).
  • Creating games using Unity.
  • Developing enterprise applications and services. 🖥️

Summary

Each of these programming and markup languages ​​serves its own unique purpose and is suitable for different tasks. Python, with its user-friendliness and rich ecosystem, is suitable for science and development, C++ and C provide high control and efficiency for systems programming, HTML is used to create web content, and C# makes it much easier to develop applications on the Windows platform.

These languages ​​are the main tools for programmers and have a large community and resources for learning, making them accessible for both beginners and experienced developers.

Computer Workshop - Arduino lessons

This week was the deadline for laboratory work with Arduino microcontrollers. We learned how to light an LED and adjust its power.

Arduino microcontrollers and LEDs

Arduino microcontrollers have become popular due to their availability and ease of use. They allow you to create many projects, including controlling LEDs. In this text, we will look at how to connect LEDs to Arduino and control them.

Program for controlling LEDs

An example of the simplest code that turns an LED on and off:

int ledPin = 9; // The pin to which the LED is connected

void setup() {
pinMode(ledPin, OUTPUT); // Setting the pin as an output
}

void loop() {
digitalWrite(ledPin, HIGH); // Turning on the LED
delay(1000); // Wait 1 second
digitalWrite(ledPin, LOW); // Turn off the LED
delay(1000); // Wait 1 second
}

item.title: 👩🏼‍🏫 Creating Markdown Presentations
item.description:
Что такое Markdown?

Markdown — is a lightweight markup language for formatting text. It allows you to quickly and easily create structured documents that can then be converted to HTML, PDF, and other formats. Markdown was created by John Gruber in 2004 to make writing for the web more convenient and readable.

Creating Presentations in Markdown Format 🌟

Presentations are a powerful tool for communicating information. Using Markdown to create them can simplify the process with its simple and concise syntax. Below are some tips and examples for creating effective presentations in Markdown.

Why use Markdown for presentations? 🤔

  • Ease: Easy to learn syntax that lets you focus on the content rather than the formatting.
  • Compatibility: Markdown can be easily converted to HTML, PDF, and other formats.
  • Tools: There are many tools and libraries for creating slides from Markdown.

Presentation tools 🛠️

  1. Reveal.js: Allows you to create beautiful and interactive presentations based on HTML. Markdown can be used to simplify the process.
  2. Pandoc: A powerful file converter tool. Allows you to convert Markdown to many formats, including PDF and HTML.
  3. Marp: Allows you to create presentations directly from Markdown files and supports integration with Visual Studio Code.

Input Criteria 📝

When creating presentations in Markdown format, it is important to keep the following criteria in mind:

  1. Clarity and Concise: Each message should be clear and concise so that the audience can easily understand it.

  2. Structure: Use headings and subheadings to clearly separate topics.

  3. Use Lists: Lists help break up the text and make it more readable.

  4. Visuals: Images and diagrams can improve comprehension and visually convey key points.

Text Formatting ✍️

Markdown supports a variety of text formatting options:

  • Bold Text: For bold text, use double asterisks or underlined characters. For example, **bold text** or __bold text__ will display as bold text.

  • Italics: For italics, use single asterisks or underlined characters. For example, *italics* or _italics_ will become italics.

  • Headings: Use a hash (#) before text to create headings. For example:

  • # Heading 1

  • ## Heading 2

  • ### Heading 3

  • Lists: Use hyphens or asterisks to create unordered lists. For ordered lists, use numbers. For example:

- Point 1
- Point 2

or

1. First point
2. Second point

Presentation outline example in Markdown

Here is an example of a slide outline:

# Presentation Title

---

## Slide 1: Introduction

- Brief introduction of the topic
- Goals and objectives

---

## Slide 2: Main idea

1. First point
2. Second point

---

## Slide 3: Conclusion

- Key takeaways
- Future plans

Interesting diagram 📊

Here is a diagram showing the structure of creating a presentation:

graph TD; A[Create a Presentation] --> B[Choose a Tool] A --> C[Structure Slide] A --> D[Input Criteria] B --> E[Reveal.js] B --> F[Pandoc] B --> G[Marp] C --> H[Headings] C --> I[Lists] C --> J[Visuals]

Conclusion 🎉

Creating presentations in Markdown format is a convenient and effective way to organize information. Use these tools and tips to make your presentations more attractive and accessible to your audience.

item.title: 🧠 Continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD).
item.description:
About the CI/CD methodology in simple terms — principles, stages, pros and cons

The CI/CD approach has been discussed a lot in IT lately.

It is often used to create applications or develop cloud solutions. But how is the work structured according to this methodology and how difficult is it to implement in practice? We will tell you about this in the article.

What is CI/CD

CI/CD (Continuous Integration/Continuous Delivery) is a development methodology that allows you to automate the process of creating software. The approach covers all stages of development: assembly, testing and deployment of software code.

In simple terms, CI/CD is an abbreviation based on the main principles of the methodology. There are only four of them:

Continuous Integration — this concept means frequent changes to code, including those located in one repository. Continuous integration allows several developers to write code at the same time: this is convenient when working on different parts of the code. Continuous Testing — automated testing of new code immediately after its integration into the repository. Tests allow you to check the code’s functionality and its compliance with quality standards. Continuous Delivery — after the program code has been tested, the procedure for preparing the code for release begins. The essence of this process is that the tested code is automatically delivered to the test environment, development environment, or production. Continuous Deployment — the stage of deploying code to the production environment: this action must be confirmed manually.

Stages of development using the CI/CD methodology

Software creation using CI/CD technology occurs in several stages. Usually, the full cycle of program development using the CI/CD principle is as follows:

Writing code. The developer writes new code and checks its functionality manually. Committing changes. At the initial stage, the developer sends an updated version of the code to a common version control system (for example, Git). Building the code and autotesting it. The development environment automatically builds the updated code and runs testing. If the tests are successful, you can move on to the next step. Manual testing. After automatic verification, the new code is transferred to testers for manual verification. Deployment. The finished code is placed on the developer’s servers. After that, a decision is made about its release. Release. After testing and fixing errors, the code is updated. Once the update is complete, the product is ready for use: customers can work with the new program, studying its functionality. Support. Customers continue to use the product and provide feedback on it. During this time, developers support the program and analyze feedback. Planning and refinement. Based on customer feedback, new functionality or reworking of the current one is planned. When the changes are planned, developers begin writing new code - at this point the cycle closes and starts over.

CI/CD is a popular software development technique with many advantages. Among them:

Reducing development time. CI/CD allows you to speed up the software creation cycle to several days (in the case of large projects, to several people). Selection of options. The CI/CD approach allows you to analyze the code before releasing it to the public. Thanks to this, you can choose the most suitable code option from several, as well as exclude dead-end code branches in time. High quality testing. The CI/CD approach combines automatic and manual tests. Thanks to this, the risk of errors in the product’s operation is reduced.

As for the disadvantages, there are only two:

Increased requirements for experience. In order for all continuous integration and delivery processes to be carried out correctly, the manager must have experience using CI/CD. This is due to the fact that the transition to a new methodology will require a complete restructuring of the rules of work and communication within the team. Constant interaction. An important part of CI/CD is communication between colleagues and individual teams. Often, an additional employee is required to debug them, who will control all stages.

item.title: 👩🏼‍🏫 Markdown markup language
item.description:
What is Markdown?

Markdown is a lightweight markup language designed for formatting text. It allows you to quickly and easily create structured documents that can then be converted to HTML, PDF, and other formats. Markdown was created by John Gruber in 2004 with the goal of making writing for the web more convenient and readable.

Why is Markdown so popular?

Markdown is easy to learn and use. Its syntax is intuitive, and the result is clean and readable text. Here are some reasons why Markdown has become a standard in various fields:

  • Simplicity: Markdown syntax is minimalistic and easy to remember.
  • Versatility: Markdown is supported by many platforms and applications, including GitHub, Reddit, Stack Overflow, and many others.
  • Portability: Markdown files are regular text files that can be opened and edited in any text editor.
  • Convertibility: Markdown files can be easily converted to HTML, PDF, and other formats.
  • Readability: Markdown text is easy to read even in its original form.

Basic elements of Markdown syntax

  • Headings: Denoted by # characters. The number of # determines the heading level.
# First-level heading
## Second-level heading
### Third-level heading
  • Lists: Can be numbered or unnumbered.
* List item 1
* List item 2

1. First item
2. Second item
  • Text highlighting: Italics (*text* or _text_) and bold (**text** or __text__).
*Italic*
**Bold**
  • Links:
[Link text](URL)
  • Images:
![Alt ​​text](URL of image)
  • Quotes: Indicated by >.
> This is a quote
  • Code: Wrapped in ` for single-line code and ``` for multi-line code.
`inline code`

```python
def hello_world():
print("Hello, world!")

Markdown Usage Examples

Markdown is widely used for writing documentation, blogging, note-taking, email writing, and more. Here are some specific examples:

  • README files: On GitHub and other code hosting platforms, Markdown is used to create README files that contain information about a project.
  • Blog articles: Many blogs use Markdown to write and format articles.
  • Documentation: Markdown is ideal for creating technical documentation.
  • Notes: Markdown makes it quick and easy to create structured notes.

Conclusion

Markdown is a powerful and easy-to-use text formatting tool. It is easy to learn and supported by many platforms and applications. If you are not using Markdown yet, give it a try - you will not regret it!

Key points:

  • Markdown is a simple and lightweight markup language.
  • It is used to format text and create structured documents.
  • Markdown is supported by many platforms and applications.
  • Markdown syntax is intuitive and easy to remember.
  • Markdown is ideal for writing documentation, blogging, taking notes, and more.
